creditline: Gift of Harry A. Brooks, Class of 1935
markings: Stamped, top of base, back: CIRE / PERDUE / A. A. HEBRARD;
inscribed:
Artist name incised, top of base, right side: Degas;
Edition incised on back: 9/20

makers.displaymaker: Edgar Degas, 1834–1917; born and died Paris, France

texts.textentryhtml: In his later years, Degas turned to modeling in wax and executed studies of his favorite subjects—horses, dancers, and women bathing—for his own pleasure. After his death, several editions in bronze were made of these works, which he had not intended for the market. Schoolgirl is an anomaly in the group. It is more portrait-like than the dancers and bathers, and, according to some accounts, this girl may have been a member of the Degas family. The sculpture’s genesis has been traced to one of the artist’s sketchbooks, in which he drew a young girl around 1881. This bronze cast is one of twenty made in 1955 after the original wax, now in the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D.C.

Like his acquaintance Gauguin, one of whose wooden relief sculptures is displayed nearby, Degas practiced sculpture later in life and created works that were unknown to the Paris art world until after his death. Modeled in wax for private enjoyment and cast in bronze decades later, most of his sculptures are explorations of the bodies and postures of bathing women or racehorses, favorite subjects in his paintings. Schoolgirl, like Little Dancer Aged Fourteen—the artist’s only sculpture displayed in his lifetime, at the sixth Impressionist exhibition of 1881—is an outlier.

bibliography.boilertext: Allen Rosenbaum and Francis F. Jones, Selections from The Art Museum, Princeton University, (Princeton, NJ: The Art Museum, Princeton University, 1986)
